captions.text: # The (Secret) City of London -- Part 1

The Great City of London, known for its historical
landmarks, modern skyscrapers, ancient markets

and famous bridges. It's arguably the financial
capital of the world and home to over eleven
*thousand* people.
Wait, what? Eleven... thousand?

That's right: but the City of London is a
different place from London -- though London

is also known for its historical landmarks,
modern skyscrapers, ancient markets, famous

bridges and is home to the government, royal
family and seven million people.

But, if you look map of London crafted by
a careful cartographer that map will have

a one-square mile hole near the middle -- it's
here where the City of London lives inside
of the city named London.

Despite these confusingly close names the
two Londons have separate city halls and elect

separate mayors, who collect separate taxes
to fund separate police who enforce separate
laws.

The Mayor of the City of London has a fancy
title 'The Right Honourable the Lord Mayor

of London' to match his fancy outfit. He also
gets to ride in a golden carriage and work

in a Guildhall while the mayor of London has
to wear a suit, ride a bike and work in an
office building.

The City of London also has its own flag and
its own crest which is awesome and makes London's
lack of either twice as sad.

To top it off the City of London gets to act
more like one of the countries in the UK than

just an oddly located city -- for uniquely
the corporation that runs the city of London

is older than the United Kingdom by several
hundred years.

So how did the UK end up with two Londons,
one inside of the other? Because: Romans.

2,000 years ago they came to Great Britain,
killed a bunch of druids, and founded a trading

post on the River Thames and named it Londonimium.
Being Romans they got to work doing what Romans

do: enforcing laws, increasing trade, building
temples, public baths, roads, bridges and
a wall to defend their work.

And it's this wall which is why the current
City of London exists -- for though the Romans

came and the Romans went and kingdoms rose
and kingdoms fell, the wall endured protecting

the city within. And The City, governing itself
and trading with the world, grew rich.

A thousand years after the Romans (yet still
a thousand years ago) when William the Conqueror

came to Great Britain to conqueror everything
and begin modern british history he found

the City of London, with its sturdy walls
more challenging to defeat than farmers on
open fields.

So he agreed to recognize the rights and privileges
City of Londoners were used to in return for
the them recognizing him as the new King.

Though after the negotiation, William quickly
built towers around the City of London which

were just as much about protecting William
from the locals within as defending against
the Vikings from without.

This started a thousand-year long tradition
whereby Monarchs always reconfirmed that 'yes'

the City of London is a special, unique place
best left to its own business, while simultaneously
distrusting it.

Many a monarch thought the City of London
was too powerful and rich. And one even built

a new Capital city nearby, named Westminster,
to compete with the City of London and hopefully,

suck power and wealth away from it. This was
the start of the second London.

As the centuries passed, Westminster grew
and merged with nearby towns eventually surrounding

the walled-in, and still separate City of
London. But, people began to call the whole

urban collection 'London' and the name became
official when Parliament joined towns together

under a single municipal government with a
mayor.

But, the mayor of London still doesn't have
power over the tiny City of London which has

rules and traditions like nowhere else in
the country and possibly the world.

For example, the ruling monarch doesn't just
enter the City of London on a whim, but instead

asks for permission from the Lord Mayor at
a ceremony. While it's not required by law,
the ceremony is, unusual to say the least.

The City of London also has a representative
in Parliament, The Remembrancer, whose job
it is to protects the City's special rights.

Because of this, laws passed by Parliament
sometimes don't apply to the City of London:

most notably voting reforms, which we'll discuss
next time. But if you're curious, unlike anywhere

else in the UK elections in the City of London
involve Medieval Guilds and modern companies.

Finally, the City of London also owns and
operates land and buildings far outside its
border, making it quite wealthy.

Once you start looking for The City's Crest
you'll find it in lots of places, but most

notably on Tower Bridge which, while being
in London is operated by City of London,

These crests everywhere when combined with
the City of London's age and wealth and quazi-independent

status make it an irresistible temptation
for conspiracy nuts. Add in the oldest Masonic

temple and it's not long before the crazy
part of the Internet yelling about secret

societies controlling the world via the finance
industry from inside the City-state of London.

(And don't forget the reptilian alien Queen
who's really behind it all.)

But conspiracy theories aside, the City of
London is not an independent nation like the

Vatican is, no matter how much you might read
it on the Internet, rather it's a unique place

in the United Kingdom with a long and complicated
history.

The wall that began all this 2,000 years ago
is now mostly gone -- so the border between

London and its secret inner city isn't so
obvious. Though, next time you're in London,

if you come across a small dragon on the street,
he still guards the entrance to the city in
a city in a country in a country.

title: The (Secret) City of London, Part 1: History

comments.author: Usammity

comments.text:
Got to love the willful ignorance and a priori wholesale dismissiveness 
towards "conspiracies." 

"Everybody knows there are no conspiracies!! Durrrrr"

• The Gulf of Tonkin really did happen as described after all.

• Nixon wasn't wiretapping political opponents.

• Carter didn't begin financing the Afghan mujahideen in the hopes of 
luring the Soviets into "their own Vietnam."

• Reagan and Casey weren't shipping crack cocaine into poor black US 
neighborhoods and using the proceeds to fund the Nicaraguan Contras.

• Bush Jr. didn't lie us into the Iraq war.

• The NSA isn't spying on all Americans.

• The CIA actually didn't overthrow democratically elected governments in 
Iran, Guatemala, Greece, Chile, Venezuela, Ukraine, and on and on. 

• The FBI didn't spy on activists, celebrities and Congressmen during the 
1960's. The didn't act like a political police.

• The CIA didn't experiment with mind-control or infect poor black people 
with syphilus. 

• Fort Knox didn't turn over US gold to the Fed as ostensible collateral 
for the national debt.

• In Operation Gladio, NATO-CIA-MI6 didn't stage false flag terror bombings 
across Western Europe then blame them on domestic communist political 
parties during the Cold War!

• There wasn't a fascist coup attempt by American business tycoons on FDR 
in 1933, foiled by Marine General Smedley D. Butler. 

• The US banks didn't profit tremendously from WWI and WWII. 

• The 1913 legislation creating the Fed was not written in secret in NJ by 
wealthy bankers such as Paul Warburg and J P Morgan. Our central bank is 
not a private cartel of the largest US banks, manipulating the money 
supply, creating the business cycle, and being run for profit.

• The 2014 legislation allowing banks to speculate with FDIC insured client 
deposits wasn't written by Citi Bank.

• FDR didn't institute numerous provocative policies against Japan in 1940, 
including an oil embargo. He hadn't broke the Japanese code and gained 
foreknowledge of the attack on Pearl Harbor. His administration never said 
they desired Japan to make the first "overt act of war" against the US. FDR 
didn't keep the Hawaiian base commanders ignorant of the overwhelming signs 
of incoming attack.

• The House Select Committee on Assassinations didn't conclude that JFK was 
killed as the result of a conspiracy.

• A court didn't not conclude that the US government was involved in 
assassinating MLK. 

"Pesky know-nothing conspiracy nuts! Always question things they shouldn't! 
Don't bother me with the facts! I've made up my mind! I'm so inculcated 
into establishment narratives that I can't even entertain the possibility 
that powerful people might get together to act in their mutual advantage! 
What kind of idiot would believe that!?" 

"Durrrrr!"﻿
comments.author: Elcapitan Picard

comments.text:
By 700 AD, the city the Romans founded was actually little more than an 
abandoned fort-shaped ruin, and almost nobody lived there. However, when 
King Alfred the Great was fortifying England against the Danes (which is 
another whole story) in the late 9th century, he rebuilt London and 
recolonized it with people. Since that time London began to actually grow 
as CGP Grey describes. For a while after the Romans left though, the city 
ceased to exist along with most of the major civilization in England for a 
while. King Arthur is speculated to have lived during the time between the 
Anglo-Saxon kingdoms and the disappearance of the Romans from England 
beginning in the early 5th century with the Roman government's increasing 
instability and fragmentation (if he did exist), but London is believed to 
have been left empty during this time with the nearest civilization a tiny 
village to the west whose residents rarely visited the ruined Roman fort.﻿

comments.author: MrOplef

comments.text:
+MrOplef I think the real issue is the miss application of the term 
conspiracy theory. 

Things like holocaust denial, reptilian theory, man never landed on the 
moon.  Don't really allege a criminal conspiracy, their just some idiotic 
hypothesis someone came up with and thought it was funny.

Where as criminal conspiracies are rather common, when the culprits are 
some low lives looking to make some quick money, they get prosecuted like 
anyone else, and go to jail.

The problem is when the culprits are highly connected individuals, it can 
be extremely difficult to investigate or prosecute.  Not to mention if the 
culprits are lawmakers.  Just as one example Nancy Pelosi and many other 
congressman recieved campaign contributions from a known terrorist group.

However long before anyone was ever able to bring them up on charges, the 
terrorist group was taken off the terrorist group list, retroactively 
making the entire affair legal.

On a much more local level, say the chief of police is a rapist.  As thats 
not to uncommon, but then what can you do about it?  In order to get an 
arrest warrant, the chief would have to sign off on his own warrant.

In order to get justice in that situation you'd need media support, 
funding, some damn good friends, and so on and so on.  So while its not 
impossible for high ranking people to get charged with a crime.  
Realistically its rather rare.

comments.text:
+mindprism
"Thise is where the problem lies, though we refer to the US as a "country", 
it is a federation of states (actual countries)."
not actual countries. the only country is usa, the states inside it have no 
unique international representation. whatever internal structure usa has 
internally is irrelevant to the world. usa is a single country, with just 
one vote in the un and in the organization of american states, and very 
other organization of which it forms part.

sorry but a city state is its own country.
washington dc is not its own country. it has no international 
representation in anything, not even sporting events and is under the 
direct control of the usa federal government.

vatican city and singapore have their own international representation and 
ambassadors, and they are not under the direct control of any other 
government.
vatican city is surrounded by italy, but it's not part of italy, and it's 
not under the control of italy.

glad we agree that the catholic church is not a country.
comments.author: sabin97

comments.text:
+sabin97

*vatican has no juristiction over anyone but itself.*
I was speaking hypothetically.

*the definition of city-state means that the city is the whole country.*
Thise is where the problem lies, though we refer to the US as a "country", 
it is a federation of states (actual countries). Thus, DC is ITS OWN 
city-state as well as the seat of the FedGov. This is essential to 
understand my "what if Italy ceded part of its sovereignty to the vatican" 
thought experiment.

Discovered Definitions:
1) Political system consisting of an independent city with sovereignty over 
a fixed surrounding area for which it served as leader of religious, 
political, economic, and cultural life.

2) a state consisting of a sovereign city and its dependencies. Among the 
most famous are the great independent cities of the ancient world, such as 
Athens, Sparta, Carthage, Thebes, Corinth, and Rome

3) A city-state is an independent city — and sometimes its surrounding land 
— which has its own government, completely separate from nearby countries. 
Monaco is a city-state. Today, there are only five city-states that are 
truly self-governing, but in the past this was more common.

4) A sovereign state consisting of an independent city and its surrounding 
territory.

5 Wiki) Additionally, several cities enjoy a high degree of autonomy 
despite formal subjection to the sovereign rule of another country and 
therefore function in large-part as city-states, and have been identified 
recently as representative of modern city-states. Hong Kong and Macau, 
along with independent members of the United Arab Emirates, most notably 
Dubai and Abu Dhabi, often are cited as such.[7][8][14] Also Washington, 
D.C., Berlin and Hamburg enjoy a high degree of autonomy within their 
states.

So, evidently I am using a broader concept of city-state than you would 
prefer, but, just as obviously, I am not abusing the term.
comments.author: mindprism

comments.text:
+mindprism
"So logically if the vatican had partial jurisdiction over Italy"
vatican has no juristiction over anyone but itself.

"You have failed to make the case of WHY being "part of" (whatever the heck 
that means) something else disqualifies something from being a city-state."
i'm baffled as to why that seems difficult to understand for you. imagine 
that any city in any country can be a city-state. that would mean all 
cities in the world are city-states.
are all the cities in the world city-states?
the definition of city-state means that the city is the whole country. for 
example singapore and vatican. those are countries composed of a single 
city.

"The vatican is "part of" the broader construct known as The Roman Catholic 
Church -- and that doesn't seem to perturb you."
are you aware that the roman catholic church is NOT a country?
comments.author: sabin97

comments.text:
+sabin97
*why would the vatican cease to be a city state?*

It is you that is asserting DC is not a city-state because it is "part of 
the US", well, it is only "part of the US" because states ceded some of 
their sovereignty to it. So logically if the vatican had partial 
jurisdiction over Italy (or any other state) then it would seemingly not be 
a city-state by your criteria.

You have failed to make the case of WHY being "part of" (whatever the heck 
that means) something else disqualifies something from being a city-state.

There is "The United States" (FedGov), and "these united States" 
(Constitution), and "the US" the collective body politic. The vatican is 
"part of" the broader construct known as The Roman Catholic Church -- and 
that doesn't seem to perturb you.
comments.author: mindprism

comments.text:
+mindprism
why would the vatican cease to be a city state?
it is physically surrounded by italy, but it's not PART of italy. it's not 
a city of italy. people who live in the vatican have vatican citizenship, 
as vatican city is the country that issues their passport.

washington dc is a city of usa. people who live in washington dc have usa 
citizenship, as usa is the country that issues their passport.
comments.author: sabin97

comments.text:

So if Italy ceded part of its sovereignty to the vatican, would the vatican 
cease to be a city state?
comments.author: mindprism

comments.text:
+mindprism
basically all of the earth is already claimed by one country or another. 
there are still some disputed places, like malvinas, and some islands 
between japan and china, and other places, but the overwhelming majority of 
the surface of the earth is taken. so planting a flag means jack shit.
planting a flag on the moon means "usa was here" nothing more. the moon 
doesnt belong to anyone.
planting 1 million flags wont change that.

washington dc is the capital city of usa. it is not a country, not even one 
of those cute little city-state ones like vatican and singapore.
the usa federal government exercises exclusive political legal and military 
control over washington dc, because USA is the country, not washington dc.
comments.author: sabin97

comments.text:
+sabin97

*a flag is merely a symbol*

You need to look at what it means when countries stick flags in soil. Its 
really neat legal magic, I think you would be impressed.

*washington dc is not a country, it's a city of usa.*

Washington DC exercises exclusive political, legal and military control 
over Washington DC. Thats the definition of a country dude.
comments.author: mindprism

comments.text:
+mindprism
"Am sure it is "part of usa" as much as the flag on the moon is"
no, that comparison doesnt really stand.
washington dc is a physical location, a flag is merely a symbol.
usa HAS colonies(and is thus an empire), however washington dc is not one 
of them. it's a piece of land that used to be part of some of the 
states(virginia and maryland i think), but it was decided that the capital 
shouldnt be part of any of the states, and thus those lands were given up 
by those states and a new city was formed.

anyway, this is all derailing from the main point. washington dc is not a 
country, it's a city of usa.
comments.author: sabin97

comments.text:
+sabin97


Am sure it is "part of usa" as much as the flag on the moon is, the 
pragmatic question and issue is -- should the Fed be looked at as a 
separate colonizing power, is this a more useful view.

I definately recall legal claims as to the applicability of the BOR when it 
comes to Fed jurisdiction. So this would erode your claim of "all federal 
laws" if true.

For instance, the residents of the FedGov are not "guaranteed a republican 
form of government" as promised by the Constitution because they have no 
representation.
comments.author: mindprism

comments.text:
+mindprism
that was quite a long post, but my point still stands. washington dc is not 
a country, it's part of usa. the problem with washington dc is that because 
it is not part of any particular state it has no vote in the usa congress. 
but being part of usa, it is subject to all federal laws.
comments.author: sabin97

comments.text:
+sabin97

I have no doubt that those born in the Territories, or in the District of 
Columbia, are so far citizens as to entitle them to the protection 
guaranteed to citizens of the United States in the Constitution, and to the 
shield of nationality abroad; but it is evident that they have not the 
political rights which are vested in citizens of the [s]tates. They are not 
constituents of any community in which is vested any sovereign power of 
government. Their position partakes more of the character of subjects than 
of citizens. They are subject to the laws of the [federal] United States, 
but have no voice in its management. If they are allowed to make laws, the 
validity of these laws is derived from the sanction of Government in which 
they are not represented. Mere citizenship they may have, but the political 
rights of [C]itizens they cannot enjoy until they are organized into a 
State, and admitted into the [u]nion.
[People v. De La Guerra, 40 Cal. 311, 342 [1870]. (Emphasis added.)]

"United States" means - (A) a Federal corporation; (B) an agency, 
department, commission, board, or other entity of the United States; or (C) 
an instrumentality of the United States. - See more at: 
http://codes.lp.findlaw.com/uscode/28/VI/176/A/3002#sthash.MPpEUfUF.dpuf
comments.author: mindprism

comments.text:
+Mike Hunt

Well, on my business account Xyz LLC, I am sole owner of the LLC, but when 
I sign checks I sign them with "President" after my name.
This is done to show I am doing this FOR my LLC, and to keep the 
responsibility on the LLC as much as possible.

So the question is, is your upper case name on the checkbook "really you" 
or is it your strawman, another legal entity. And if you are not signing as 
an agent of that entity, you may be liable for things you are not otherwise 
liable for,

comments.author: Sam Carruthers

comments.text:
+Sam Carruthers a better footing? 16 nations? Since it encompasses 16 
nations what shared values can 16 nations have other than being 
Anglo-Saxon. What military alliance? Please explain to me how you can have 
16 nations at opposite ends of the earth in a military alliance? EU has 27 
nations in close proximity with easy trade access. My paternal ancestors 
come from the Isle, blood connections are always a good thing to have. 
Scotland already said that they desire to be part of the Commonwealth 
trading relationship.
comments.author: dan Jones

comments.text:
+dan Jones This is about the Commonwealth Realms, the sixteen nations that 
have Queen Elizabeth II as Head of State. Not the UK running the shop. We 
have more similar systems of government, a shared language, a common 
history and culture. The EU would love such similarities and symbolism 
between most of their member states but they don't have it. What they do 
have is a flag and an anthem most people in the UK don't care about. People 
in other EU states don't care much for it either. I didn't even mention 
Rule Britannia but if you want you can to sing your new EU anthem. What 
would make a stronger USA is a more closely tied Anglo-sphere. The UK still 
doesn't even share information with other EU states that it would with New 
Zealand or the USA. Canada and the UK are now sharing embassies to cut 
costs and Australia are thinking of doing the same. Btw New Zealand and 
Australia have freedom of movement and very close cooperations. They are 
not doing it because the UK is involved. They are doing it because they 
know they have the similarities I've just spoken of. So this is already 
happening without UK involvement.
comments.author: Sam Carruthers

comments.text:
" By speaking with a common voice on the world stage, the Commonwealth 
Realms could maximise their collective and individual influence and 
opportunities, benefit from a better footing when interacting with other 
significant powers such as the United States, European Union, and rising 
Asian countries, and better ensure their shared values continue to be heard 
in a changing world." That is what the EU is trying to accomplish. You 
would be a counterforce to the US, who is helping Australia defend itself? 
The rUK is in no position to defend Australia. Rule Brittania?
